articles.headline: VW’s Crisis Strategy: Forward, Reverse, U-Turn
articles.snippet: Volkswagen made serious mistakes in its public response to the uproar over cheating on diesel emissions, and it is still scrambling to correct them.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen made serious mistakes in its public response to the uproar over cheating on diesel emissions, and it is still scrambling to correct them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Someday, Volkswagen’s emissions cheating scandal will be studied in crisis communications textbooks. And not in a good way.

articles.headline: Top Lobbyist for Drug Makers Threads a Thicket of Outrage
articles.snippet: Stephen Ubl, who became head of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America late last year, is facing rising criticism of the industry.
articles.abstract: Stephen Ubl, who became head of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America late last year, is facing rising criticism of the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few lobbyists have walked into the kind of political inferno that greeted Stephen J. Ubl when he became the top pitchman for the pharmaceutical industry.

articles.headline: Chris Christie Endorses Donald Trump and Calls Marco Rubio ‘Desperate’
articles.snippet: The endorsement from Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who bowed out of the presidential race on Feb. 10 after a disappointing sixth-place finish in New Hampshire, comes a day after Donald J. Trump came under withering attacks from his rivals at ...
articles.abstract: The endorsement from Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who bowed out of the presidential race on Feb. 10 after a disappointing sixth-place finish in New Hampshire, comes a day after Donald J. Trump came under withering attacks from his rivals at the latest Republican debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a rollicking day of spectacle, spite and scorn, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey declared his allegiance to Donald J. Trump and war on Marco Rubio, describing the senator on Friday as desperate and unfit for the presidency.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: For Black Women in South Carolina, It’s Clinton’s Turn
articles.snippet: In 2008, 98 percent of African-American women cast their ballots for Barack Obama. Now, many hope to end the long, unbroken line of men running the nation.
articles.abstract: In 2008, 98 percent of African-American women cast their ballots for Barack Obama. Now, many hope to end the long, unbroken line of men running the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jackie DeBose woke up early on Sunday, well before sunrise, grabbed her rhinestone-bedazzled Obama hat and her vintage “Hillary for President” button, loaded her suitcase in the trunk of her Lexus and headed to pick up three friends for a road trip to South Carolina.

articles.headline: Melissa Harris-Perry Walks Off Her MSNBC Show After Pre-emptions
articles.snippet: She said that her show had effectively been taken away from her and that she felt “worthless” in the eyes of NBC News executives.
articles.abstract: She said that her show had effectively been taken away from her and that she felt “worthless” in the eyes of NBC News executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusually public flare-up, one of MSNBC’s television personalities clashed with the network on Friday in a dispute about airtime and editorial freedom and said she was refusing to host the show that bears her name this weekend.

articles.headline: Apple’s Privacy Fight Tests Relationship With White House
articles.snippet: The encryption debate and the government’s legal action against Apple have created more tension between the company and the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The encryption debate and the government’s legal action against Apple have created more tension between the company and the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, was relentless during a private meeting of tech giants and President Obama’s top national security officials last month. Encrypted devices like the iPhone are here to stay, he insisted. Law enforcement needs to find a way to do its job in a new world.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Syria Truce Comes With Price, but Not for Assad
articles.snippet: European and Israeli intelligence officials believe the pause in fighting may consolidate President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power.
articles.abstract: European and Israeli intelligence officials believe the pause in fighting may consolidate President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the temporary cease-fire in Syria begins to take hold on Saturday, despite the low expectations of the American and Russian officials who negotiated the agreement, it will be a landmark event. For the first time, diplomacy will have succeeded in abating the killing and misery that have already led to more than 250,000 deaths and millions of refugees pouring out of the shattered country.

articles.headline: ‘The Revenant’ Author Michael Punke Has a Day Job
articles.snippet: Michael Punke is the United States ambassador to the World Trade Organization, a role that is seriously limiting his celebrity.
articles.abstract: Michael Punke is the United States ambassador to the World Trade Organization, a role that is seriously limiting his celebrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are five literary adaptations in the Oscar race for best picture this year, including movies based on Emma Donoghue’s “Room” and Colm Tóibín’s “Brooklyn.” But among the hopeful novelists who will be closely watching Sunday’s Academy Awards ceremony, only one has negotiated a $1.3 trillion global trade deal.

articles.headline: Inside the Republican Party’s Desperate Mission to Stop Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Despite all the forces arrayed against Mr. Trump, a paralytic sense of indecision and despair has prevailed.
articles.abstract: Despite all the forces arrayed against Mr. Trump, a paralytic sense of indecision and despair has prevailed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Get live updates about the Florida primary.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Wins South Carolina Primary
articles.snippet: Drawing overwhelming support from African-American voters, Mrs. Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign.
articles.abstract: Drawing overwhelming support from African-American voters, Mrs. Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Drawing overwhelming support from the African-American voters who deserted her here eight years ago, Hillary Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign in South Carolina on Saturday, delivering a blow to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont as their fight turns to the 11 states where Democrats vote on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: What It’s Really Like to Risk It All in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: An entrepreneur tries to start a company and raise venture capital in Silicon Valley — and then finds out she is pregnant.
articles.abstract: An entrepreneur tries to start a company and raise venture capital in Silicon Valley — and then finds out she is pregnant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Nathalie Miller decided to walk away from Instacart, the grocery delivery start-up now worth more than $2 billion, she made a spreadsheet to analyze how much money she was leaving on the table.

articles.headline: Scientists Protest Cuts and Commercialization at Australian Climate Center
articles.snippet: A decision by Australia’s science agency to lay off researchers and focus more on commerce threatens climate studies around the globe.
articles.abstract: A decision by Australia’s science agency to lay off researchers and focus more on commerce threatens climate studies around the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Perched on a wild, windy promontory on the rugged tip of northwestern Tasmania, the tiny Cape Grim research station has been measuring airborne greenhouse gases since 1976.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall
articles.snippet: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
articles.abstract: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Mahmoud Jibril cleared customs at Le Bourget airport and sped into Paris, the American secretary of state had been waiting for hours. But this was not a meeting Hillary Clinton could cancel. Their encounter could decide whether America was again going to war.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker and Scott Shane

articles.headline: A New Libya, With ‘Very Little Time Left’
articles.snippet: The fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seemed to vindicate Hillary Clinton. Then militias refused to disarm, neighbors fanned a civil war, and the Islamic State found refuge.
articles.abstract: The fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seemed to vindicate Hillary Clinton. Then militias refused to disarm, neighbors fanned a civil war, and the Islamic State found refuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a grisly start to the new era for Libya, broadcast around the world. The dictator was dragged from the sewer pipe where he was hiding, tossed around by frenzied rebel soldiers, beaten bloody and sodomized with a bayonet. A shaky cellphone video showed the pocked face of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, “the Leader” who had terrified Libyans for four decades, looking frightened and bewildered. He would soon be dead.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Overdraft Practices Continue to Gut Bank Accounts and Haunt Customers
articles.snippet: These banking fees are borne by ordinary consumers, disproportionately by the poorest among them, and many miss details tucked into fine print.
articles.abstract: These banking fees are borne by ordinary consumers, disproportionately by the poorest among them, and many miss details tucked into fine print.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angelina Lemus was puzzled. She had no idea why every month as much as $96 was disappearing from her Citibank checking account.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: After Tense Weeks, Melissa Harris-Perry’s MSNBC Show Is Canceled
articles.snippet: Her departure comes after she said she felt “worthless” to NBC News executives after several weeks of pre-emptions of her show.
articles.abstract: Her departure comes after she said she felt “worthless” to NBC News executives after several weeks of pre-emptions of her show.
articles.lead_paragraph: It all began to unravel for Melissa Harris-Perry four weeks ago.

articles.headline: Trying to Revive H.M.O.s, but Without Those Scarlet Letters
articles.snippet: The plans are making a comeback, but they are so tainted by their poor reputation that insurers and companies try to avoid calling them H.M.O.s.
articles.abstract: The plans are making a comeback, but they are so tainted by their poor reputation that insurers and companies try to avoid calling them H.M.O.s.
articles.lead_paragraph: An H.M.O. by any other name is still an H.M.O.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Elicits Shock and Biting Satire in European Media
articles.snippet: Once dismissive of Mr. Trump’s presidential candidacy, European news media are adjusting to the prospect of a seemingly unstoppable Trump juggernaut.
articles.abstract: Once dismissive of Mr. Trump’s presidential candidacy, European news media are adjusting to the prospect of a seemingly unstoppable Trump juggernaut.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — He has been depicted as a snarling demagogue in France, equated with Donald Duck in Spain, and described as worse than Lord Voldemort in Britain.

articles.headline: Obama’s Tangled History With Supreme Court Sets Stage for Nominee Fight
articles.snippet: President Obama’s current standoff with the Senate over replacing Justice Antonin Scalia is a struggle over not just the law, but power and his own legacy.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s current standoff with the Senate over replacing Justice Antonin Scalia is a struggle over not just the law, but power and his own legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first time President Obama sat down to pick a new Supreme Court justice, surprised aides discovered that he had gone beyond the briefing memos to read the leading candidate’s past judicial rulings. The president, a onetime constitutional law teacher, was in his element, a “legal nerd,” as one aide called him, putting theory into practice.

articles.headline: Why a Push for Online Privacy Is Bogged Down in Washington
articles.snippet: The initiative has produced few data controls for consumers, even as advocates say the need is greater because of new​ web-connected gadgets.
articles.abstract: The initiative has produced few data controls for consumers, even as advocates say the need is greater because of new​ web-connected gadgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February 2012, the White House introduced a blueprint for the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights, intended to give Americans the ability to exercise control over what personal details companies collected from them and how the data was used.

articles.headline: The Promise of Artificial Intelligence Unfolds in Small Steps
articles.snippet: Five years after a computer won “Jeopardy,” excitement over A.I. is at a peak, but the commercial potential of the achievement will take some years to be realized.
articles.abstract: Five years after a computer won “Jeopardy,” excitement over A.I. is at a peak, but the commercial potential of the achievement will take some years to be realized.
articles.lead_paragraph: When IBM’s Watson computer triumphed over human champions in the quiz show “Jeopardy!” it was a stunning achievement that suggested limitless horizons for artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: On the Campaign Trail: G.O.P. Race Grows Cruder and More Aggressive
articles.snippet: Senator Marco Rubio has lunged headfirst into a bout with Donald J. Trump, reflecting a conclusion that his above-the-fray approach is ineffective.
articles.abstract: Senator Marco Rubio has lunged headfirst into a bout with Donald J. Trump, reflecting a conclusion that his above-the-fray approach is ineffective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Join us for live updates and analysis of Super Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Christie Splits With His Past in Backing Trump
articles.snippet: Gov. Chris Christie’s carefully calibrated endorsement of Donald J. Trump, though not all his policies, reflected the competing impulses he and many of his supporters are feeling.
articles.abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s carefully calibrated endorsement of Donald J. Trump, though not all his policies, reflected the competing impulses he and many of his supporters are feeling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Join us for live updates and analysis of Super Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Chemical Safety Bill Could Help Protect Monsanto Against Legal Claims
articles.snippet: A single paragraph in the sweeping legislation could shield the company from costly liability for making the now-banned chemicals known as PCBs.
articles.abstract: A single paragraph in the sweeping legislation could shield the company from costly liability for making the now-banned chemicals known as PCBs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing hundreds of millions of dollars in lawsuits, the giant biotechnology company Monsanto last year received a legislative gift from the House of Representatives, a one-paragraph addition to a sweeping chemical safety bill that could help shield it from legal liability for a toxic chemical only it made.
